After initial coronavirus infection, immune responses appear effective in controlling viral infection, suggesting that vaccines should be feasible. There were important caveats from animal vaccine models: antibody responses waned quickly, indicating that immune responses might not be long-lasting.
18 Also, in one mouse coronavirus model of SARS, natural killer cell, antibody, and interferon responses were beneficial, but T-cell responses paradoxically worsened outcomes.
19 Accordingly, vaccines will need to demonstrate safety and effectiveness before widespread adoption.
